title.narrative: Red hot pepper solution for crop raiding elephants around the Bia Conservation Area, Ghana

description.narrative: This project is working to mitigate human elephant conflict in agricultural areas outside Bia National Park in Ghana. Specific activities will include 1) training sessions for at least 50 farmers and twenty agricultural extension officers and wildlife officers on passive and active elephant deterrent methods, including chilli grease fences and briquettes, 2) Construction and maintenance of three demonstration farms in each of four villages surrounding the Bia area (Anwiefutu Nkwanta, Yamediagoro, Kofi Kyere, and Nyamebekyere), 3) Evaluating the effectiveness of the various deterrent approaches.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

title.narrative: Marine Turtle Conservation Fund

description.narrative: The recipient will implement night patrols on 10 km of sea turtle nesting beach within the Muni-Pomadze Ramsar site to protect nests and nesting females, conduct 10 sea turtle conservation education programs in local communities and weekly radio programs about wildlife conservation, and train 5 community members to conduct sea turtle surveys and ecotourism turle walks.

title.narrative: Expanding the local capacity to integrate research, education, and ecotourism into meaningful sea turtle management strategies in Ghana.

description.narrative: This project will conduct daily night patrols on 10 km of nesting beach within the Muni-Pomadze Ramsar site between November 15, 2014 -February 28 to protect leatherback and olive ridely nests and nesting females; will conduct 20 sea turtle conservation education programs in local communities and weekly radio programs about wildlife conservation; and train 10 community members to conduct sea turtle surveys and ecotourism turle walks.

title.narrative: Wildlife Without Borders-Amphibians In Decline

description.narrative: The project will maintain a viable wild population of the critically endangered Togo slippery frog in Ghana. Specific objectives include: (1) institute a community-based amphibian sanctuary (protected area) in the Togo-Volta Hills; (2) Restore tree cover to 10 hectares of critical frog habitat by December 2015; (3) Reduce the consumption of the critically endangered Togo slippery frog in the Togo-Volta Hills by 50% by December 2015.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

title.narrative: Expanding the role of Ghanaians in sea turtle conservation activities in central Ghana, Africa

description.narrative: The recipient will implement daily night patrols on 10 km of sea turtle nesting beach within the Muni-Pomadze Ramsar site November 15, 2016 -February 28 to protect nests and nesting females; conduct sea turtle conservation education programs in local communities and weekly radio programs about wildlife conservation; train community members to conduct sea turtle surveys and ecotourism turle walks; and train 15 community members as observers to collect sea turtle bycatch data on local artisanal fishing boats.

title.narrative: Status and Conservation of the Critically Endangered Western Chimpanzee in Southwestern Ghana

description.narrative: : 1) conducting surveys to determine chimpanzee abundance and distribution in nine protected areas; 2) documenting and mapping threats to chimpanzees in those areas; and 3) conducting genetic sampling to provide genetic data to aid population management.

title.narrative: PROTECTING GHANA S ENDANGERED SEA TURTLES AT MAJOR NESTING BEACHES THROUGHOUT THE COUNTRY

description.narrative: Funds under this award are to be used to implement a sea turtle conservation program in Ghana focused on leatherback and olive ridley sea turtles. The intent is to address severe threats from poaching of meat and eggs of nesting turtles and nests and to work with artisanal fisherman to reduce accidental bycatch. Activities include: 1)rconduct daily night patrols on 10 km of sea turtle nesting beach within the Muni-Pomadze Ramsar site November 15 -February 28 to protect nests and nesting females and expand to a 20 km beach in Keta that has high leatherbacknesting ; 2) conduct sea turtle conservation education programs in local communities and weekly radio programs about wildlife conservation; and 3) train community members to conduct sea turtle surveys and ecotourism turle walks.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

title.narrative: ELEPHANT CONSERVATION THROUGH LAW ENFORCEMENT AND COMMUNITY OUTREACH AT MOLE NATIONAL PARK AND ITS CORRIDORS-GHANA

description.narrative: The goal of the proposed project is to maintain the integrity of the Parks ecosystem and its adjoining corridors with particular emphasis on the long-term sustainable conservation of this important elephant population.

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: ELEPHANT CONSERVATION THROUGH LAW ENFORCEMENT AND COMMUNITYOUIREACH AT MOLE NATIONAL PARK AND ITS CORRIDORS-GHANA

description.narrative: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ENSURE THE INTEGRITY OF THE ELEPHANT POPULATION IN GHANA S MOLE NATIONAL PARK AND ITS CORRIDORS THROUGH IMPROVED LAW ENFORCEMENT OPERATIONS AND ENHANCED COMMUNITY COLLABORATION. MOLE NATIONAL PARK IS THE COUNTRY S LARGEST PROTECTED AREA AND, ACCORDING TO THE NATIONAL WILDLIFE AUTHORITY, CONTAINS THE LARGEST AND ONLY VIABLE POPULATION OF ELEPHANTS IN GHANA, LAST ESTIMATED AT AROUND 400 INDIVIDUALS. AS ELSEWHERE IN WEST AFRICA, ELEPHANTS HERE FACE A COMBINATION OF MOUNTING PRESSURES, INCLUDING POACHING FOR THE ILLEGAL IVORY TRADE, HABITAT FRAGMENTATION E.G., LOGGING AND AGRICULTURE AND HUMAN-ELEPHANT CONFLICT. SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES INCLUDE 1 SUPPORT FOR PARK RANGERS, INCLUDING GROUND PATROLS, TRAINING AND EQUIPMENT 2 PUBLIC ENGAGEMENT AROUND THE PARK, INCLUDING SUPPORT FOR COMMUNITY VOLUNTEERS TO REPORT THE PRESENCE OF ELEPHANTS TO PARK AUTHORITIES, TRAINING AND ASSISTANCE FOR FARMERS TO MANAGE HUMAN-ELEPHANT CONFLICT, AND COLLABORATION WITH COUNTERPARTS TO MANAGE FOR ECOLOGICAL CONNECTIVITY 3 SENSITIZATION OF THE JUDICIARY E.G., PROSECUTORS AND JUDGES TO FOSTER STRONGER PUNITIVE SANCTIONS ON ELEPHANT CRIMES BROUGHT BEFORE THE COURTS AND 4 MONITORING AND REPORTING OF ILLEGAL KILLING OF ELEPHANTS, WILDLIFE TRAFFICKING, AND HUMAN-ELEPHANT CONFLICT.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date
